text: Hey there GRRR Travelers!
Thanks for joining me again today.

In India so far, I've probably had a total
of two guesthouse hotels that have actually
had internet.
However, the wifi was often very spotty.

So today I thought I'd go ahead and share
with you a video on getting an Indian SIM
in India.

I always have this way of being redundant
and I'm not sure why.
It's when I'm totally not prepared.
I finally got my Indian SIM card.
This means that I can finally surf the internet.

I went ahead and got a data plan that cost
me 1800 no, 1,081 rupees.

I put on around 50 or 60 rupees onto my talk
time.

Altogether that was the total I spent on my
one sim and a data plan.
And that was for a 5GB 3 G speed plan.

It's unlimited but then after 5GB, it slows
down to 2g... and god knows what else.

This should last me 28 days, which is almost
a month and it's good enough for me.

If I used up all my 5GB and wanted to refresh
it, then I would just go ahead an pay another
1,080 rupees.

In many cases, trailers will get hteier sim
cards from little shops and street stores,
and that's fine.
Even if it looks a little shady and what not.

Even the official stores that sell the sims
or the service providers.

They'll telll l you that you can go to any
one o those shops an you can go and top them
off or add minutes to your sim card.
Sometimes vendors will sell you a used SIM.

A few days later your SIM shuts off and that
happened to me before.

That's kind of stressful thing to be kinda
like, be running back and forth and saying
"Why does my sim not work?'

In the past I've gone to Vodaphone and I've
gone to a Vodaphone store.
And it still shut off on me.
Vodaphone was the only option I had.

This time I went to the official store, just
so that someone was accountable.

I think Airtel is the number one provider
for a lot of India.
Vodaphone is like ehhâ€¦

I'm just giving them a second try because
they were the only one that was available.
You can try Idea.
So far, these three top brands are GSM networked.

So if you have a CDMA phone, which you should
look into, they might not be work with that.

Just do your research before you go ahead
and buy a SIM.

Getting an Indian SIM is easy and yet not.
You'll need your official documents.

You'll need your passport so they can xerox
a copy of your information page.

And they'll also want to xerox a copy of your
visa.

I went with the e- online visa on arrival
visa.

Two passport photos preferably 2 inches by
2 inches.

You will need a contact or a personal reference
in India.

My hotel, they kinda, gave me their business
card as well as a a copy of the receipt.

You will need a contact or a personal reference
in India.

Initially I went in, paid 5 rupees for my
sim card and presented all my document to
them.
That was around 6:30 at night.

And then in the morning my card started to
receive a signal.

By midday I went back to the store where I
got to recharge my minutes, where I had rupees
for talk minutes as well as, a data pan.

That's where I told them what data plan I
waned.

All that was activated at least by 2 o'clock
in the afternoon..

It's been a full day of sightseeing for me
and filming.

Now I need to charge everything, load all
my photos onto my laptop and pack up so I
can leave tomorrow.
So it's going to be a long evening.

But anyways I wanted to get this video out
for you all.

Give me thumbs up or like, subscribe to my
channel.

Travel safe, smart and fun. May the GRRR be
with you!
